June 22, 2008: Fiction
NOTHING TO LOSE, by Lee Child. (Delacorte, $27.) Jack Reacher exposes the
secrets of a Colorado town.
THE HOST, by Stephenie Meyer. (Little, Brown, $25.99.) Aliens have taken
control of the minds and bodies of most humans, but one woman won’t surrender.
PLAGUE SHIP, by Clive Cussler with Jack Du Brul. (Putnam, $26.95.) Juan
Cabrillo and the crew of the Oregon must determine what happened on a cruise
ship full of dead bodies.
LOVE THE ONE YOU’RE WITH, by Emily Giffin. (St. Martin’s, $24.95.) A woman’s
happy marriage is shaken when she encounters an old boyfriend.
BLOOD NOIR, by Laurell K. Hamilton. (Berkley, $25.95.) The vampire hunter
Anita Blake is involved in a scandal that threatens the master vampire Jean-
Claude’s power.
CHASING HARRY WINSTON, by Lauren Weisberger. (Simon & Schuster,
$25.95.) Three glamorous friends, New York women nearing 30, vow to change
their lives.
ODD HOURS, by Dean R. Koontz. (Bantam, $27.) Odd Thomas, who can
communicate with the dead, confronts evil forces in a California coastal town.
SUNDAYS AT TIFFANY’S, by James Patterson and Gabrielle Charbonnet. (Little,
Brown, $24.99.) A woman finds an unexpected love.
DEATH AND HONOR, by W. E. B. Griffin and William E. Butterworth IV. (Putnam,
$26.95.) A Marine pilot spies in Argentina in 1943; the fourth book in the Honor
Bound series.
SNUFF, by Chuck Palahniuk. (Doubleday, $24.95.) An aging porn queen aims to
have sex on film with 600 men.
DEVIL MAY CARE, by Sebastian Faulks. (Doubleday, $24.95.) James Bond
tracks a dangerous executive amid cold war tensions with the help of a beautiful
girl.
PHANTOM PREY, by John Sandford. (Putnam, $26.95.) The Minneapolis
detective Lucas Davenport investigates a string of murders of young Goths.
SHADOW OF POWER, by Steve Martini. (Morrow, $26.95.) The lawyer Paul
Madriani searches for a missing letter from Thomas Jefferson that might explain a
scholar’s murder.
THE FRONT, by Patricia Cornwell. (Putnam, $22.95.) A Massachusetts state
investigator and his team from “At Risk” confront a rogue association of municipal
Non-Fiction
WHEN YOU ARE ENGULFED IN FLAMES, by David Sedaris. (Little, Brown,
$25.99.) The humorist’s latest essays deal with middle age, mortality and giving up
smoking.
WHAT HAPPENED, by Scott McClellan. (PublicAffairs, $27.95.) A former White
House press secretary regrets that “I allowed myself to be deceived” by top
officials.
THE POST-AMERICAN WORLD, by Fareed Zakaria. (Norton, $25.95.) The rise of
China and India and the global distribution of power.
AUDITION, by Barbara Walters. (Knopf, $29.95.) A personal and professional
memoir.
ARE YOU THERE, VODKA? IT’S ME, CHELSEA, by Chelsea Handler. (Simon
Spotlight Entertainment, $24.95.) Humorous personal essays from the stand-up
comedian.
THE DOWNHILL LIE, by Carl Hiaasen. (Knopf, $22.) The Florida novelist takes up
golf again after 32 years.
ALWAYS BY MY SIDE, by Jim Nantz with Eli Spielman. (Gotham, $26.)
Remembering two decades with CBS Sports, with a focus on father-son
relationships.
STOLEN INNOCENCE, by Elissa Wall. (Morrow, $25.95.) The star witness
against the polygamous sect leader Warren Jeffs describes how he forced her to
marry her first cousin when she was 14.
ME OF LITTLE FAITH, by Lewis Black. (Riverhead, $24.95.) The stand-up
comedian’s essays about religion focus on what we believe and why.
THE REVOLUTION, by Ron Paul. (Grand Central, $21.) A libertarian manifesto
from the Texas congressman.
A WOLF AT THE TABLE, by Augusten Burroughs. (St. Martin’s, $24.95.) A
memoir of life with a cruel father.
THE LAST CAMPAIGN, by Thurston Clarke. (Holt, $25.) Robert Kennedy’s 1968
campaign for the presidency.
UP TILL NOW, by William Shatner with David Fisher. (Thomas Dunne/St. Martin’s,
$25.95.) Captain Kirk’s autobiography.
MY STROKE OF INSIGHT, by Jill Bolte Taylor. (Viking, $24.95.) A brain scientist
shares what she learned from her 1996 stroke, which produced a sense of
euphoria when it damaged her left brain.
